Wow Peter, that is fast work!

Assigning node-centric values is a legitimat=
e research problem.  The 
simplest answer is that a CPPN can have more than=
 a single output.  
There can be additional outputs for things like biases =
and learning 
rates.  Each such property will then be patterned across the =
substrate 
just like weights.

However, the one problem that comes up with =
nodes is that node-centric 
properties are overspecified by a 4D CPPN becau=
se nodes are specified 
by only two dimensions (that is, they are points in=
 space rather than 
lines).  Therefore, you have to set a convention for wh=
en to read the 
value of a node-centric output and assign it to a node.  Fo=
r example, 
you could say that the node at x1 y1 is set to the value of the=
 node 
output only when x2 y2 are both zero.  Of course there are many 
alt=
ernative ways it could be done, but some convention must be set.  

ken

--=
- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>

2D
